getDomain

public int[] getDomain()
Description copied from interface: Expression
!!! This method can only be used when parameters are all known !!!

Returns the domain of the current expression, that is, the upper and lower bound of the expression. If the expression is an sparse-domain variable, the sparse domain will be returned. If the expression consists of a sparse domain element, this element is mapped to a bounds element.
The first list-element is the smallest element. If only one value is returned, the Expression is a constant (or a decision variable with lb=ub)

Returns:

isSmallerThanSameType

public char isSmallerThanSameType(Expression e)
Ordering of sums: Sums are ordered according to their amount of elements: a sum with a smaller amount of elements is smaller than a sum with a higher amount of elements. Sums can have positive and negative elements. Since the + operator is smaller than the - operator, positive elements precede negative elements and sums consisting of solely positive elements are smaller than sums containing negative elements (assuming they have the same amount of elements). Examples:
a + b
< a - b
< - a - b
< a + b + c
< a + b - c

evaluate

public Expression evaluate()
Description copied from interface: Expression
This method evaluates the object expression. It's type might change! Please note that the result from evaluation is better if the expression has been ordered first!

reduceExpressionTree

public Expression reduceExpressionTree()
Description copied from interface: Expression
Optimises the expression tree: merges adjacent n-ary nodes of the same type such that linear sums or conjunction can be detected and represented by a single n-ary node in the expression tree (instead of several binary nodes).

Returns:
